If the transformation \\(g(z)\\) is applied to a vector \\(z_0\\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\(\\frac{d}{dt}z(t) = Dz(t)\\) without further intervention, will \\(z(T)\\) at time T be equivalent to if \\(z_0\\) was just directly evolved to t = T under \\(\\frac{d}{dt}z(t) = Dz(t)\\)?
Explanation: Applying \\(g(z)\\) changes the initial condition to \\(Ke^{M0}z_0 = Kz_0\\), altering the starting point of the system. Radiating effects due to the matrix \\(K\\) interfaced with \\(D\\)'s dynamics render the evolved state at time T distinct from merely advancing \\(z_0\\) under \\(D\\).
